title: Online Relationships and Safety
subject: Health and Physical Education
description: This topic explores online communication, cyberbullying, image-based abuse, protecting yourself online, and help-seeking strategies. Students learn to recognise and respond to online risks while building healthy digital relationships.

Investigate the benefits of relationships and examine their impact on their own and others' health and wellbeing
Analyse factors that influence emotional responses and devise strategies to self-manage emotions in increasingly unfamiliar situations

A.title: Online Relationships and Safety - Foundation
A.levelDescription: Students working 2-3 years below the expected level will focus on basic online safety concepts, recognising kind and unkind online behaviour, and knowing trusted adults to tell when something feels wrong.
A.contentAdaptations: Uses simple language, visual supports, concrete examples from familiar apps, and focuses on basic safety rules. Emphasises telling a trusted adult and blocking/reporting.

contentSections.title: Being Safe Online
contentSections.content: The internet is used for lots of things like games, videos and talking to friends. Just like in real life, we need to follow safety rules online. Some important rules are: keep your password secret, don't share private information like your address, and only talk to people you know in real life. If something online makes you feel uncomfortable or worried, that's a sign you should tell a trusted adult.

contentSections.title: Kind and Unkind Online Behaviour
contentSections.content: Online, people should treat each other the same way they would in person - with kindness and respect. Kind online behaviour includes sending nice messages, including others, and being helpful. Unkind behaviour includes sending mean messages, leaving people out on purpose, or sharing things about someone that are embarrassing. If someone is unkind to you online, it's not your fault.

contentSections.title: What to Do When Something Goes Wrong
contentSections.content: If something online makes you feel bad, scared or confused, there are things you can do. First, don't reply to mean messages - this can make things worse. You can block the person so they can't contact you. You can report the behaviour to the app or website. Most importantly, tell a trusted adult like a parent, teacher or counsellor. You can also take a screenshot to show what happened.

contentSections.title: Trusted Adults Who Can Help
contentSections.content: A trusted adult is someone who will listen to you, believe you, and help you. This might be a parent, carer, teacher, school counsellor, or another family member. It's okay to ask for help when something online upsets you. Trusted adults can help you report problems, block people, and feel better. If one adult doesn't help, you can ask another one.

relational.stem: Explain why keeping your password secret helps keep you safe online.
relational.modelResponse: Keeping your password secret helps keep you safe online because it stops other people getting into your accounts. If someone knows your password, they could pretend to be you and send messages that aren't really from you. They might also see your private information or change things in your account. A secret password means only you can access your things.
relational.rubric: Explains the connection between password secrecy and online safety. Shows understanding that passwords protect accounts from unauthorised access. May mention risks of someone accessing their account.

extendedAbstract.stem: Think about how online safety is similar to staying safe in real life. What are some things that are the same?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Online safety is similar to real life safety in several ways. Just like we don't tell strangers our address in person, we shouldn't share it online. We have trusted adults to help us with problems both online and offline. Being kind to people matters both places. We should walk away from mean people in real life, just like we should block them online. Both need us to speak up when something is wrong.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Makes meaningful connections between online and real-world safety. Identifies parallel concepts such as stranger danger, trusted adults, kindness, and speaking up about problems. Shows ability to apply safety principles across contexts.

contentSections.title: Types of Cyberbullying
contentSections.content: Cyberbullying can happen in many ways. Harassment is sending mean, rude or threatening messages repeatedly. Exclusion is deliberately leaving someone out of online groups or chats. Spreading rumours is sharing false information about someone online. Impersonation is pretending to be someone else to damage their reputation. Outing is sharing someone's private information or secrets without permission. Trolling is posting upsetting comments to get a reaction. All types of cyberbullying can cause real harm.

contentSections.title: Understanding Digital Footprints
contentSections.content: Every time you go online, you leave behind a digital footprint. This includes things you post, like, share, and search for. Photos you upload, comments you make, and accounts you create all become part of your digital footprint. Unlike footprints in sand, digital footprints can last forever and be seen by many people including future schools or employers. This is why it's important to think before you post - would you be happy if everyone saw this?

contentSections.title: Responding to Cyberbullying
contentSections.content: If you experience cyberbullying, there are steps you can take. First, don't respond - this often makes things worse. Save evidence by taking screenshots of the messages. Block the person so they can't contact you. Report the behaviour to the app or website. Most importantly, talk to a trusted adult who can help you. Remember, cyberbullying is never the target's fault, and you deserve support.

contentSections.title: Being a Positive Bystander
contentSections.content: If you see someone being cyberbullied, you can help. Don't join in or forward mean messages. Support the person being targeted - send them a kind message privately. Report the bullying behaviour. Tell a trusted adult about what's happening. By standing up against cyberbullying, you can make a real difference. It takes courage, but bystanders have the power to change the situation.

multistructural.modelResponse: Four types of cyberbullying are: 1) Harassment - sending mean messages repeatedly, 2) Exclusion - leaving someone out of online groups, 3) Spreading rumours - sharing false information about someone, 4) Impersonation - pretending to be someone else online.

relational.stem: Explain how a bystander can help stop cyberbullying and why their actions matter.
relational.modelResponse: A bystander can help stop cyberbullying in several connected ways. They can refuse to forward or like mean messages, which stops the content from spreading. They can send a supportive private message to the target, which helps them feel less alone. They can report the bullying to the platform and tell a trusted adult. Their actions matter because bullies often want an audience - when bystanders don't go along with it, the bully loses their power. The target also feels supported instead of isolated.
relational.rubric: Explains multiple ways bystanders can help and connects these to why they make a difference. Shows understanding that bystander action reduces bullying power and supports the target.

extendedAbstract.stem: How might thinking about your digital footprint now help you in the future? Give examples.
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Thinking about your digital footprint now helps you in the future because the things you post today could be seen by schools, universities and employers later. For example, if you post kind and thoughtful comments, this shows future employers you're professional. If you share achievements and interests, it creates a positive impression. But embarrassing photos or mean comments could hurt your chances of getting into a school program or getting a job. Also, your digital footprint affects your friendships - people might judge you now and in the future by what you post. By being thoughtful now, you're protecting your future reputation.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Extends thinking beyond the present to consider future implications. Gives specific examples of how digital footprint could affect opportunities. Shows understanding that online choices have long-term consequences for reputation and opportunities.

reflectionQuestions: What would you want your digital footprint to say about you?

contentSections.title: Understanding Cyberbullying and Its Impacts
contentSections.content: Cyberbullying involves using technology to deliberately and repeatedly harm someone. It differs from face-to-face bullying because it can happen 24/7, reach a large audience instantly, and be difficult to escape. Impacts on targets can include anxiety, depression, social withdrawal, declining school performance, and in severe cases, self-harm. The effects can be long-lasting as content may persist online. Understanding these impacts helps us recognise why cyberbullying is serious and why intervention matters.

contentSections.title: Image-Based Abuse
contentSections.content: Image-based abuse involves sharing intimate or sexual images of someone without their consent. This includes sharing images that were originally shared privately, taking images without permission, or threatening to share images. In Australia, image-based abuse is illegal. Victims are never to blame - the responsibility lies with the person who shares without consent. If you become aware of image-based abuse, never forward the images. Report to the platform and tell a trusted adult. The eSafety Commissioner can help have images removed.

contentSections.title: Protecting Privacy and Safety Online
contentSections.content: Protecting yourself online involves multiple strategies. Use strong, unique passwords and enable two-factor authentication. Regularly review privacy settings on all platforms. Be selective about what you share and who can see it. Think critically about friend requests from people you don't know. Be aware that information shared online can be screenshotted and spread. Trust your instincts - if someone online makes you uncomfortable, you can block them. Remember that people online may not be who they claim to be.

contentSections.title: Help-Seeking for Online Issues
contentSections.content: When facing online problems, there are multiple pathways for help. Trusted adults like parents, teachers and counsellors can provide immediate support. Most platforms have reporting functions for abuse. Kids Helpline (1800 55 1800) and eheadspace offer support. The eSafety Commissioner can help with serious cyberbullying, image-based abuse, and illegal content. Police should be contacted if there are threats of violence. Remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, and you deserve support when dealing with online harm.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the effectiveness of three different strategies for addressing cyberbullying. Consider the advantages and limitations of each.

Strong responses weigh multiple factors.

Identifies both advantages and limitations of each

create.question: Create an action plan for your school to address cyberbullying, including prevention, response, and support components.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive plan with multiple components. Prevention might include education programs, positive digital citizenship campaigns. Response might include clear reporting procedures, consequences for perpetrators, investigation processes. Support might include counselling access, peer support programs, communication with families. Plan should be practical and appropriate for a school setting.

Outlines response procedures

relational.stem: Explain how being an upstander rather than a bystander can reduce the harm caused by cyberbullying.
relational.modelResponse: Being an upstander rather than a bystander reduces harm in several connected ways. When someone supports the target - by sending a kind message, standing up publicly, or reporting the behaviour - it shows the target they're not alone, which reduces feelings of isolation and helplessness. Upstander action also signals to the bully that their behaviour is not acceptable, potentially making them reconsider. When multiple bystanders become upstanders, it shifts the social dynamic - bullies often rely on audience approval or silence. Upstanders who report ensure adults can intervene. All these factors combine to reduce both the immediate harm and the ongoing impact of cyberbullying.
relational.rubric: Explains multiple ways upstander behaviour helps and connects these to reduced harm. Shows understanding of how upstander action supports victims, challenges bullies, and changes social dynamics.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider why someone might not seek help when experiencing online abuse. What systemic changes could make help-seeking easier?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: People may not seek help for online abuse for many reasons: fear of having devices taken away, embarrassment about the content, concern they won't be believed, fear of retaliation, not knowing who can help, feeling they caused it, or past negative experiences when seeking help. Systemic changes that could improve this include: schools teaching about help-seeking in a non-judgmental way, clear and simple reporting processes on all platforms, adults responding supportively rather than punitively, anonymous reporting options, counsellors trained in online abuse, awareness campaigns normalising help-seeking, peer support programs, faster response from platforms and authorities, and education campaigns for adults about supportive responses. These changes address both practical barriers and emotional obstacles to seeking help.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies multiple barriers to help-seeking and proposes meaningful systemic changes. Shows sophisticated understanding of why young people may not report and how systems could be improved. Connects barriers to specific solutions.

reflectionQuestions: What aspects of online safety do you find most challenging to manage?
Have you ever seen someone being an upstander online? What did they do?
What would make it easier for young people to seek help for online issues?

contentSections.title: Societal Factors Contributing to Online Harm
contentSections.content: Online harm doesn't occur in a vacuum - it reflects broader societal issues. Gender inequality contributes to disproportionate targeting of women and girls through harassment and image-based abuse. Racism, homophobia, and other forms of discrimination are amplified online. The anonymity or perceived distance online can reduce empathy and increase harmful behaviour. Social norms that tolerate disrespect in relationships are reflected online. Platform design that prioritises engagement over safety can amplify harmful content. Understanding these factors helps us address root causes rather than just symptoms.

contentSections.title: Platform Responsibility and Accountability
contentSections.content: Social media platforms have significant power to shape online experiences. Current debates focus on platform accountability: Are platforms doing enough to prevent and respond to harm? Should they be legally liable for harmful content? How should they balance free speech with safety? Research shows that platform design choices - such as algorithms that promote conflict, features that enable harassment, and inadequate reporting systems - contribute to harm. Advocates push for greater transparency, faster response to reports, and design changes that prioritise user safety.

contentSections.title: Australia's Regulatory Approach
contentSections.content: Australia has developed one of the world's more comprehensive approaches to online safety regulation. The eSafety Commissioner has powers to remove harmful content and issue penalties. The Online Safety Act 2021 addresses cyberbullying, image-based abuse, and illegal content. Platforms operating in Australia must have reporting mechanisms and respond to removal notices. However, challenges remain: the global nature of the internet, encryption limiting content detection, and platforms' resistance to regulation. Ongoing policy debates focus on strengthening protections while respecting privacy and free expression.

contentSections.title: Advocacy for Safer Online Environments
contentSections.content: Young people can be powerful advocates for online safety. This might include: educating peers about respectful online behaviour; participating in school or community campaigns; providing feedback to platforms about safety features; sharing experiences (when safe) to raise awareness; supporting friends experiencing online harm; and engaging with policy discussions. Effective advocacy is informed by understanding the issues, focuses on systemic change, and centres the experiences of affected people. Youth voice is particularly valuable because young people understand the online landscape.

remember.question: What is algorithmic amplification in the context of online harm?

options.text: When algorithms block all harmful content automatically
options.feedback: This describes content moderation, not algorithmic amplification.

options.text: When platform algorithms promote harmful or conflict-generating content because it drives engagement
options.feedback: Correct! Algorithmic amplification occurs when platform systems promote harmful content because it generates more clicks and reactions.

options.text: When users share content with many followers
options.feedback: This is user-driven sharing, not algorithmic amplification.

options.text: When the volume on videos is automatically increased
options.feedback: Algorithmic amplification refers to content promotion, not audio settings.

understand.question: How do societal issues like gender inequality contribute to online harm?

options.text: They don't - online harm is unrelated to offline society
options.feedback: Online and offline behaviour are connected. Societal attitudes influence online behaviour.

options.text: Gender inequality leads to women and girls being disproportionately targeted for harassment and image-based abuse
options.feedback: Correct! Research shows that gender inequality contributes to women and girls experiencing higher rates of online harassment and image-based abuse.

options.text: Gender inequality only affects people offline, not online
options.feedback: Gender inequality manifests in both online and offline spaces.

options.text: Gender inequality means men are never targets of online harm
options.feedback: Men can also experience online harm, but patterns show gender inequality contributes to disproportionate targeting of women and girls.

apply.question: A social media platform is redesigning its reporting system. Applying your understanding of effective online safety measures, which improvement would be most effective?

options.text: Making reports anonymous so the reported person doesn't know who reported them
options.feedback: While anonymity can help, this alone doesn't address response times or outcomes.

options.text: Adding more steps to the reporting process to reduce false reports
options.feedback: Adding barriers discourages reporting and doesn't improve safety.

options.text: Creating a faster response system with clear timelines and communication about outcomes
options.feedback: Correct! Research shows that fast, transparent responses to reports improve user safety and trust in reporting systems.

options.text: Requiring users to provide their real identity before reporting
options.feedback: This could deter reporting and put reporters at risk of retaliation.

analyse.question: Analyse the tension between platform free speech claims and user safety. What are the key considerations on each side?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple perspectives. Free speech considerations: concerns about censorship, different cultural standards, risk of over-moderation, importance of open discourse. Safety considerations: harm to vulnerable users, power imbalances, platforms are private companies not governments, false equivalence between 'both sides'. Strong responses recognise this is complex and identify how different design choices affect this balance.
successCriteria: Identifies key arguments from both perspectives
Recognises the complexity of balancing these values
Analyses how platform design choices affect this balance
Avoids oversimplification of either position

evaluate.question: Evaluate Australia's regulatory approach to online safety. What are its strengths and what could be improved?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should evaluate strengths such as: dedicated eSafety Commissioner, legal powers to remove content, focus on protecting young people, comprehensive legislation. Areas for improvement might include: global enforcement challenges, response times, proactive prevention rather than reactive removal, addressing algorithmic harm, ensuring platforms implement changes. Strong responses are balanced and evidence-informed.
successCriteria: Identifies specific strengths of Australia's approach
Identifies specific areas for improvement
Provides reasoning for evaluative judgments
Demonstrates understanding of regulatory challenges

create.question: Create an advocacy campaign to promote safer online environments among young people. Include your key messages, strategies, and how you would measure impact.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive advocacy campaign. Key messages should be clear and evidence-based. Strategies might include peer education, social media campaigns, school programs, engaging with platforms. Impact measurement should include both process measures (reach, engagement) and outcome measures (behaviour change, reporting rates). Campaign should centre youth voice and address systemic issues.
successCriteria: Develops clear, evidence-based key messages
Proposes multiple strategies appropriate for reaching young people
Includes methods for measuring campaign impact
Addresses systemic factors, not just individual behaviour

unistructural.stem: What is one power that Australia's eSafety Commissioner has to address online harm?
unistructural.modelResponse: The eSafety Commissioner can order platforms to remove harmful content.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one power such as removing content, issuing penalties, investigating complaints, or requiring platforms to have safety measures.

multistructural.stem: List four societal factors that contribute to online harm.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four societal factors that contribute to online harm are: 1) Gender inequality leading to disproportionate targeting of women, 2) Racism and discrimination being amplified online, 3) Social norms that tolerate disrespect in relationships, 4) Platform designs that prioritise engagement over safety.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four distinct societal factors. May include gender inequality, racism, discrimination, social norms, platform design, anonymity effects, or lack of digital literacy.

relational.stem: Explain how platform design choices and societal attitudes work together to create online harm.
relational.modelResponse: Platform design choices and societal attitudes work together in creating online harm. Platforms are designed to maximise engagement, and content that provokes strong emotions (including outrage and conflict) generates more engagement. When societal attitudes include prejudice or tolerance for disrespect, these attitudes find expression online - and platform algorithms then amplify this harmful content because it drives engagement. For example, misogynistic content may get many reactions (positive and negative), so algorithms promote it, exposing more people to these attitudes. Additionally, platform features like anonymity or weak reporting systems can enable harmful behaviour that reflects offline prejudices. The combination means that societal attitudes are not just reflected online but actively amplified by platform design.
relational.rubric: Explains the interaction between platform design and societal factors. Shows understanding that platforms amplify existing attitudes and that design choices can enable or reduce harm. Connects multiple factors in a coherent analysis.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how a 'consent culture' could transform online environments. What would need to change at individual, community, platform, and policy levels?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: A consent culture transforming online environments would require changes at multiple levels. At the individual level, people would internalise asking permission before sharing content about others, respecting when someone says no to interactions, and recognising that consent is ongoing. At the community level, peer groups would reinforce these norms, call out violations, and support those whose boundaries are crossed. At the platform level, design changes could include consent features for tagging and sharing, friction points that prompt users to consider consent, and robust systems for reporting violations. At the policy level, laws would clearly criminalise sharing without consent with meaningful penalties, education would be mandated, and platforms would be held accountable for enabling violations. These levels interact - legal frameworks support platform changes, platform design reinforces community norms, and community norms shape individual behaviour. Transforming online spaces requires addressing all levels simultaneously.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Proposes changes at multiple levels of society and shows how these interact. Demonstrates sophisticated understanding of systemic change. Connects abstract concept (consent culture) to concrete changes. Shows understanding that transformation requires coordinated action across levels.

reflectionQuestions: What responsibility do you think platforms have for the harm that occurs on their services?
How could young people be more effectively included in online safety policy discussions?
What systemic changes would most improve online safety for young Australians?
selfAssessment: I can analyse how societal factors contribute to online harm
I can evaluate the responsibilities of different stakeholders in online safety
I can develop advocacy strategies for safer online environments
studentReflection.connectionToLife: As digital citizens, you have a role in shaping online environments - not just through your own behaviour, but through advocacy for systemic change. Understanding the complex factors that contribute to online harm equips you to push for meaningful improvements.

E.title: Online Relationships and Safety - Extension
E.levelDescription: Students working 2+ years above the expected level will synthesise research on online harm, evaluate global approaches to digital safety, and design innovative solutions that address root causes while respecting human rights.
E.contentAdaptations: Engages with academic research, global policy comparisons, ethical frameworks, and complex systemic analysis. Encourages original thinking about emerging challenges and innovative solutions.
learningIntentions: I am learning to synthesise research on the causes and impacts of online harm
I am learning to evaluate global approaches to digital safety through ethical and human rights frameworks
I am learning to design innovative solutions that address root causes of online harm
successCriteria: I can synthesise research to explain the complex causes and impacts of online harm
I can evaluate global approaches to digital safety using ethical and human rights criteria
I can design innovative solutions that address root causes while considering potential unintended consequences
prerequisites: Advanced understanding of online safety issues and regulatory approaches
Ability to analyse systemic and societal factors
Familiarity with ethical frameworks and human rights concepts

vocabularyTerms.definition: The concept of a nation or individual having control over their digital presence and data
An approach that embeds safety features into products and platforms from the earliest design stages
The interconnected nature of social categorisations such as race, gender, and class, which create overlapping systems of discrimination or disadvantage
An approach to policy that grounds decisions in internationally recognised human rights principles
Taking preventive action when an activity raises threats of harm, even without full scientific certainty
An approach that focuses on repairing harm through inclusive processes rather than punishment
The belief that technology alone can solve complex social problems, often overlooking structural factors
The gap between those with effective access to digital technology and those without

contentSections.title: Research on Online Harm: Causes and Impacts
contentSections.content: Research on online harm reveals complex, interconnected causes. Individual factors include anonymity effects, reduced empathy at a distance, and normalisation through exposure. Social factors include peer influence, in-group/out-group dynamics, and existing inequalities (gender, race, sexuality) being amplified. Technological factors include algorithmic amplification of conflict, platform designs prioritising engagement, and inadequate safety features. Research on impacts shows psychological harm (anxiety, depression, trauma), behavioural effects (self-censorship, withdrawal), and broader social effects (silencing of marginalised voices, democratic harm). Intersectionality is crucial - those facing multiple forms of marginalisation experience compounded online harm.

contentSections.title: Global Approaches to Digital Safety
contentSections.content: Countries take different approaches to online safety, reflecting different values and priorities. The EU's approach emphasises data protection and privacy (GDPR) with recent additions addressing online harm. The UK's Online Safety Act creates duties of care for platforms with Ofcom as regulator. Australia's approach through the eSafety Commissioner focuses on removal powers and platform accountability. The US has taken a more hands-off approach, with Section 230 protecting platforms from liability. Authoritarian regimes use 'safety' rhetoric to justify censorship. Evaluating these approaches requires considering effectiveness at reducing harm, protection of human rights including free expression, enforcement challenges, and potential for misuse.

contentSections.title: Safety by Design Principles
contentSections.content: Safety by design embeds user safety into products from the earliest development stages, rather than adding protections later. Key principles include: design dignity (treating users with respect), user empowerment (giving users control over their experience), risk assessment (proactively identifying potential harms), and continuous improvement (updating based on emerging harms). This contrasts with reactive approaches that wait for harm to occur before responding. Implementing safety by design requires platforms to prioritise safety alongside engagement and profit, which may require regulatory incentives. Critics note that even well-designed platforms exist within broader social contexts that generate harm.

contentSections.title: Designing Innovative Solutions
contentSections.content: Addressing online harm requires innovative thinking that goes beyond current approaches. Potential directions include: AI-assisted harm detection with human oversight; restorative justice approaches that focus on accountability and repair rather than just punishment; education integrated throughout schooling; economic models that don't incentivise engagement at any cost; youth participation in platform governance; and addressing offline inequalities that drive online harm. Effective solutions likely combine technological, social, educational, and regulatory elements. Critical evaluation of proposed solutions should consider effectiveness, unintended consequences, equity implications, and human rights compatibility.

remember.question: What does 'safety by design' mean in the context of digital platforms?

options.text: Adding safety features after problems arise
options.feedback: This describes a reactive approach, the opposite of safety by design.

options.text: Embedding safety features into products from the earliest design stages
options.feedback: Correct! Safety by design means building safety into platforms from the start, not as an afterthought.

options.text: Making platforms completely safe from all possible harm
options.feedback: No approach can eliminate all harm; safety by design reduces harm through thoughtful design.

options.text: Hiring designers who specialise in online safety
options.feedback: While expertise matters, safety by design is a principle about when and how safety is integrated, not just who does it.

understand.question: Why is an intersectional analysis important when studying online harm?

options.text: Because it focuses only on the most common forms of harm
options.feedback: Intersectionality actually helps reveal harm experienced by those facing multiple marginalisation, not just common harms.

options.text: Because people facing multiple forms of marginalisation experience compounded harm that single-axis analysis misses
options.feedback: Correct! Intersectional analysis reveals how overlapping identities (e.g., being both a woman and a person of colour) can lead to unique and compounded experiences of online harm.

options.text: Because it simplifies the analysis by focusing on one factor at a time
options.feedback: Intersectionality actually adds complexity by examining how multiple factors interact.

options.text: Because online harm affects everyone equally regardless of identity
options.feedback: Research shows online harm disproportionately affects marginalised groups and those with intersecting marginalised identities.

apply.question: Apply safety by design principles to a new social media platform being developed for teenagers. Which feature would best exemplify these principles?

options.text: A reporting button added after launch in response to complaints
options.feedback: Adding features after launch in response to problems is reactive, not safety by design.

options.text: Algorithms optimised purely for engagement to build the user base quickly
options.feedback: Engagement-optimised algorithms often amplify harmful content, contradicting safety by design.

options.text: Built-in friction before sharing that prompts users to consider how their post might affect others
options.feedback: Correct! Building prompts into the sharing process from the start embeds safety into the platform's core functionality.

options.text: A terms of service that users must agree to, prohibiting bullying
options.feedback: Terms of service alone are reactive measures; safety by design changes how the platform actually functions.

analyse.question: Analyse the tension between privacy protections and content moderation in online safety. How might end-to-end encryption both protect and potentially harm users?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should analyse multiple dimensions. Privacy benefits: protection from surveillance, safety for activists and minorities, preventing data breaches. Safety concerns: inability to detect harmful content, challenges investigating crimes, difficulty protecting children. Students should recognise this as a genuine dilemma without simple solutions, and may discuss approaches like metadata analysis, user reporting, or client-side scanning (with their own concerns). Strong responses avoid suggesting one value should simply override the other.
successCriteria: Explains how encryption protects privacy and safety
Analyses how encryption can complicate harm prevention
Recognises this as a complex tension rather than simple trade-off
May propose approaches that attempt to balance these values

evaluate.question: Evaluate the concept of 'techno-solutionism' in online safety. What are the limits of technological solutions, and what other approaches are needed?

shortAnswer.rubric: Students should critique over-reliance on technology. Limits of tech solutions: don't address underlying social attitudes, can be circumvented, may have unintended consequences (over-blocking), can't capture context and nuance, may entrench biases. Other approaches needed: education, cultural change, addressing offline inequality, restorative approaches, policy and regulation, platform accountability. Strong responses recognise that technology has a role but must be part of comprehensive approach.
successCriteria: Clearly explains what techno-solutionism is and its limitations
Identifies specific limits of technological approaches
Proposes complementary approaches beyond technology
Demonstrates nuanced view that technology has a role but not sole role

create.question: Design an innovative framework for addressing online harm among young people that incorporates insights from research, respects human rights, and addresses root causes. Explain and justify your design choices.

shortAnswer.rubric: Students create a comprehensive framework with multiple components. Should address: prevention (education, cultural change), platform design (safety by design principles), response (reporting, support, accountability), and recovery (restorative approaches). Should incorporate research insights about causes of harm. Should consider human rights (privacy, expression, safety, participation). Should address root causes (inequality, social norms) not just symptoms. Should anticipate and address potential unintended consequences. Strong responses justify design choices with reasoning.
successCriteria: Framework addresses prevention, response, and recovery
Incorporates research insights about causes of online harm
Considers human rights implications
Addresses root causes, not just symptoms
Anticipates potential unintended consequences
Provides clear justification for design choices

unistructural.stem: What is one criticism of techno-solutionism in addressing online harm?
unistructural.modelResponse: One criticism is that technological solutions don't address the underlying social attitudes that cause online harm.
unistructural.rubric: Identifies one valid criticism such as: doesn't address root causes, can be circumvented, may have unintended consequences, or can't capture context.

multistructural.stem: List four principles of safety by design for digital platforms.
multistructural.modelResponse: Four principles of safety by design are: 1) Design dignity - treating users with respect, 2) User empowerment - giving users control over their experience, 3) Risk assessment - proactively identifying potential harms, 4) Continuous improvement - updating based on emerging harms.
multistructural.rubric: Lists four relevant safety by design principles. May include dignity, empowerment, risk assessment, transparency, continuous improvement, or accessibility.

relational.stem: Explain how research on the causes of online harm informs effective intervention strategies.
relational.modelResponse: Research on causes of online harm directly informs intervention strategies. Research showing algorithmic amplification of harmful content suggests interventions targeting platform design. Research on anonymity effects informs decisions about identity verification or friction in posting. Research on social norms suggests education and cultural change programs. Research on intersectionality indicates that interventions must consider how different groups experience harm differently. Understanding that harm reflects offline inequalities means addressing those root causes is necessary. Effective interventions are multi-layered, addressing individual, social, and technological factors identified in research, rather than focusing on just one dimension.
relational.rubric: Connects specific research findings to intervention strategies. Shows understanding that research should drive intervention design. Identifies interventions at multiple levels corresponding to different causes.

extendedAbstract.stem: Consider how emerging technologies (such as AI, virtual reality, or the metaverse) might create new forms of online harm and new opportunities for safety. What principles should guide the development and regulation of these technologies?
extendedAbstract.modelResponse: Emerging technologies create both new risks and opportunities. AI could enable sophisticated harassment (deepfakes, personalised abuse at scale) but also improved harm detection. VR and metaverse create immersive environments where harassment feels more physical and intimate, raising new questions about virtual assault. These technologies may be adopted faster than regulation can keep pace. Guiding principles should include: the precautionary principle (acting on potential harms before they're proven); safety by design (embedding protections from the earliest stages); human rights compatibility (new technologies shouldn't enable new violations); participatory governance (affected communities should shape development); transparency (understanding how systems work); accountability (clear responsibility for harm); and adaptability (frameworks that can evolve with technology). These principles acknowledge uncertainty while providing ethical grounding. Regulation should be technology-neutral where possible, focusing on outcomes and harms rather than specific technologies.
extendedAbstract.rubric: Identifies new forms of harm from emerging technologies. Proposes principles that could guide development and regulation. Shows sophisticated understanding of challenges in regulating emerging technologies. Considers multiple stakeholder perspectives. Principles are ethically grounded and practically applicable.
